channel.title: BBC News - Health

item.title: Coronavirus levels continue to fall across the UK
item.description: ONS officials say they are seeing welcome falls in infection across the UK, but levels remain high.

item.title: Sleepless nights for women due to HRT shortage
item.description: MP says supplies in her Hampshire constituency have run out, leaving some women 'unable to sleep'.

item.title: Cancer: Huge DNA analysis uncovers new clues
item.description: An "archaeological dig" of thousands of tumours in the UK has unearthed new patterns in cancer's DNA.

item.title: Longest Covid infection lasted more than 16 months, tests show
item.description: UK doctors who treated the patient at a London hospital say persistent infections are still rare.

item.title: Spike in child hepatitis cases linked to common virus
item.description: UK child hepatitis cases rise to 108, with a common virus increasingly likely to be the trigger.

item.title: Periods: TikTok gives better education than schools, say teens
item.description: Young women say they learn more about periods outside school as a report reveals shortcomings.

item.title: York eating disorder clinic served unsafe food - report
item.description: Inspectors found "unsafe and unacceptable food provision" at the Schoen Clinic in York.

item.title: Covid: Tain family ends more than two years self isolation
item.description: The Arthurs stayed at home to protect seven-year-old twins Orin and Olivia who have a rare disease.

item.title: NHS to ban products of slavery after PPE concerns
item.description: A campaign group says it is the biggest step in removing forced labour from supply chains in years.

item.title: Covid: Woman caught virus twice within record 20 days
item.description: Spanish researchers say it's the shortest-known gap between two coronavirus infections.

item.title: I decided not to let cancer stop me dating
item.description: Katherine Crowson was 29 when she was diagnosed, and wanted to know when she would get her life back.

item.title: What's the problem with calories on restaurant menus?
item.description: The new rules are taking away the joy of going out for a meal for some people with eating disorders.

item.title: Ulcerative colitis: 'I was going to the toilet up to 30 times a day'
item.description: Two young women with ulcerative colitis share photos of their stoma bags to normalise the condition.

item.title: 'I felt more joy than I thought possible'
item.description: How it feels to treat your depression with a hallucinogenic drug.

item.title: Childhood hepatitis: Why are we seeing an unusual spike in cases?
item.description: Health authorities in Scotland and England are looking into 71 unusual cases of the illness.

item.title: Covid: Nine new symptoms added to official list
item.description: Sore throats, headaches and loss of appetite are now all officially recognised as signs of infection.

item.title: Have I got Covid, a bad cold or something else?
item.description: What are the new Covid symptoms, and when should I stay at home?

item.title: Is a virus we all have causing multiple sclerosis?
item.description: Scientists think they have now uncovered a mystery cause of this incurable disease.

item.title: 'I've had long Covid for two years now'
item.description: Why are so many people still living with long Covid after two years and are there any hopes for treatment?

item.title: Covid: Why are so many people catching it again?
item.description: As Covid continues to spread rapidly, are many people catching Omicron for a second time?

item.title: Rules on free lateral flow and PCR Covid tests published
item.description: The list of who can get free tests after 1 April in England is now out, but most people will have to pay.

item.title: Ukraine war: The road to safety for Ukraine's cancer children
item.description: About 200 hospitals worldwide are offering safe cancer treatment for boys like Pavlo and Kyril.

item.title: Why I gave a kidney to a work colleague
item.description: When Ninon Ferguson offered to donate an organ to someone at work, he thought she was joking.

item.title: Alzheimer's: Neil Kinnock supporting wife through disease
item.description: The ex-Labour leader says his wife Glenys, who has Alzheimer's, has been "a continent of rocks".

item.title: Ukraine: Premature babies struggling for life in bombed cities
item.description: Doctors have begun seeing a sharp rise in the number of preterm births in some areas of Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine war: WHO says attacks on health facilities are rising daily
item.description: The World Health Organization has verified more than 70 attacks on hospitals and healthcare facilities.

item.title: 'I was shocked to find out I now have four kidneys'
item.description: Transplant patient Stuart Middleton has both his kidneys - along with two he received from donors.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: What's behind the latest surge?
item.description: What lies behind the surge in cases that has delayed the lifting of the final restrictions?

item.title: Covid trapped me at home for more than seven months
item.description: But a vaccine - the first time one has been used to treat Covid - set Ian Lester free.

item.title: Cost of living: 'It feels like I'm being priced out of existence'
item.description: Some disabled people say they are switching off their heating to cope with spiralling energy bills.

item.title: Omicron vs Zero-Covid: How long can China hold on?
item.description: China's worst outbreak in two years has got some questioning how long it can hang on to its strategy.

item.title: In Mariupol, children bear the brunt of Vladimir Putin's war
item.description: At a children's hospital near the besieged city, the true impact of Russia's tactics are on display.

item.title: The 48-hour journey with medics taking aid to Ukraine
item.description: Volunteers are racing medical supplies from the UK to the Ukrainian front line.

item.title: Covid-19: Is the world ready for a great reopening?
item.description: We asked our journalists around the world to give us a snapshot of life two years into the pandemic.

item.title: 'Dangerous' tanning products promoted by influencers
item.description: Sprays and injections containing "melanotan-2" may lead to cancer, doctors tell a BBC News investigation.

item.title: Menopause: The Bedfordshire clinic that is 'changing lives'
item.description: Sam Price says help is available for women who are "all over the place" due to the menopause.

item.title: Reproductive coercion: 'I wasn't allowed to take my pill'
item.description: A BBC poll suggests 50% of UK women under 45 have experienced a form of reproductive coercion.

item.title: Covid: What is the guidance on mask-wearing now?
item.description: Almost all of the UK's Covid rules have ended, two years after they were introduced.

item.title: What are the Covid variants and do vaccines still work?
item.description: Some people who have been vaccinated have still been catching Omicron.

item.title: How will the vulnerable be protected from Covid? And other questions
item.description: The government has announced the end of all Covid restrictions in England.

item.title: End of Covid regulations: What if I'm still worried?
item.description: What would ending isolation rules in England mean for people who are worried about getting Covid?

item.title: Omicron: How do I know if I have it?
item.description: The symptoms are similar to a cold, while genetic analysis is the only way to confirm the variant.

item.title: Covid: How to look after yourself at home
item.description: What can you expect if you have Covid, and when should you get extra help?

item.title: Covid vaccine ‘waning immunity’: How worried should I be?
item.description: Is the effectiveness of Covid vaccines waning over time? We look at how much protection being double vaccinated offers.

item.title: Covid booster: Who can get the fourth jab and how do you book it?
item.description: Over-75s and those with a weakened immune system are being offered an extra booster dose this spring.

item.title: Why bonding over the Euros appeared to increase Covid cases in men
item.description: Psychologists say men need to be part of a group in order to vent their feelings and emotions.

item.title: Covid: Why are 12-15s now being double-jabbed?
item.description: All children aged 12 to 15 are being offered two doses of Covid vaccine.

item.title: Why you shouldn't get a second Covid jab too early
item.description: A government scientific advisor tells Newsbeat why four weeks is too soon between Covid jabs.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Covid rules: How can the clinically vulnerable stay safe?
item.description: As social-distancing and other Covid rules end in England, how can people who were shielding stay safe?

item.title: What are the latest rules for face coverings and masks?
item.description: Rules around face coverings are easing across the UK but they are still required in some settings.

item.title: How many cases in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can teenagers get a second dose?
item.description: All 16 and 17 year-olds in the UK can now have a second dose 12 weeks after the first.

item.title: How do we know Covid vaccines are safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Coronavirus: What it does to the body
item.description: What is it like to have the coronavirus, how will it affect you and how is it treated?

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: How to get a Covid test
item.description: Most people in England no longer get free PCRs or LFTs, and rules vary across the rest of the UK.

item.title: All you need to know on the coronavirus
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms of coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the risk to men over 50?
item.description: While most people will have mild symptoms and recover quickly, some are more prone to getting sick.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do face masks actually work?
item.description: With face masks in high demand, we look at whether they really can protect people from the virus.

item.title: 'My cancerous tumour was as big as a kettle bell'
item.description: Stephanie Coles found a strange lump growing in her stomach area.

item.title: Brain cancer DNA research hopes to speed up diagnosis
item.description: More than 200 brain tumour patients are taking part in research hoping to yield new personalised treatments.

item.title: MND: 'It's like a hand grenade going off in your body'
item.description: A man living with motor neurone disease says he tries to stay upbeat despite the "cruel" illness.

item.title: 'I planned to end my life at 16 but I'm still here'
item.description: Chelsea, from Nottingham, experienced low mood, anxiety and self-harm.

item.title: 'Life without Covid rules is much worse than we thought'
item.description: Vaccines and treatments have helped many in the UK but Isabel, 11, is among those still at risk.
